title: Part of an Arch with the Nile God and Earth Goddess

museum_location.name: This item is not on view

completeness.name: Best
completeness.description: All data has been vetted. Objects generally have quality photos and descriptions.

labels.title: Multiple: 61.128, 41.1226, 41.891
labels.content: In pagan Egyptian tombs, the deceased was often identified with suitable figures in Greco-Roman mythology. This was particularly apparent in the relief decoration of arches designed to curve out and over the heads of visitors to the public part of the tomb. Like the fragmentary examples here, they might show the god of the Nile to recall an authoritative family man, or a nymph to symbolize a young woman. Some wall reliefs, such as the example here showing Hercules as a mature hero, probably served the same commemorative purpose.

collections.name: Egyptian, Classical, Ancient Near Eastern Art
